content.description:
This route is in a corridor in the North Hollywood formation. From the Lesbian Lust boulder, head east through a notch, and scramble up to the corridor.

This is a short hand crack on the north side of the corridor.

Boulder up to a high first bolt, clip it and then lieback your way up the sharp arete, with good feet, to shared anchors with Lesbian Lust. The crux comes just past the last bolt and is a little steeper than the rest of the route with more rounded hands and smears for the feet.

Excellent rock and engaging moves earn this two stars out of five.
content.location:
This route climbs the other side of the same arete with

Lesbian Lust

.

climbs.name: Open Container
climbs.fa: Dave Stoner, Terry McCarthy & Geoff Archer, October 1989

content.description:
The northwest face of the Zsa Zsa Gabor Memorial Boulder is where you'll find this short but fun route on excellent rock.

Begin just right of a triangular cutout on the north side of the boulder and lieback/smear your way along a low-angled arete to a creaky stance below a high first bolt. Steep friction on polished rock past the first bolt is the crux with more positive holds soon appearing in time for the small runout to the second bolt. Easy moves lead to the top and the anchors.

Note: The stance below the first bolt is on a creaking flake which doesn't inspire much confidence; although it doesn't seem to move if it breaks off the climb will become much harder.   Given 5.8 in the Vogel guide this is definitely harder than that and while short it's worth a spin if in the area. One star out of five.

climbs.name: Marsupial Lust
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, George Armstrong, Tom Burke, Derek Reinig, Tucker Tech

content.description:
This climb isn't actually on the Zsa Zsa Gabor Memorial Boulder but is found on another large boulder directly behind it (visible in photo).

A reachy start on jugs leads into a devious crux past the first bolt which heads left to awkward lieback moves past the second bolt. Continue liebacking past the third bolt to gain a small ledge (optional 0.5" cam placement); above large flakes lead to the anchor. Descent is via a walk- off down the right side of the boulder.

Although short the moves are engaging and played out on good rock in a pleasant setting. One star out five.

climbs.name: Lesbian Lust
climbs.fa: Geoff Archer, Dave Stoner & Terry McCarthy, October 1989

content.description: This is a classic arÃªte climb on fantastic rock.  Well protected, excellent position, and sustained moves.  This route alone is worth the hike.  It gets morning sun.

Directly behind the boulder with

Marsupial Lust

(5.10a) is where you'll find this short north-facing route.

Committing but easy moves above a bad landing lead to the first bolt (climbers 6' or taller may be able to stem off a boulder and clip the first bolt) above which fun and well protected moves up large edges lead to rap anchors on a ledge.

Like a lot of the routes in the area this is on the short side but it does have some fun moves and good rock...so give it a whirl. One star out of five.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 2 bolt anchor w/ Metolius rap hangers (all 3/8")

content.description:
Start just right of a triangular cutout at the base of the rock and climb straight up the face using steep smears and tiny handholds on impeccable stone. The crux comes at about two-thirds height as you transition slightly to the right, although it stays independent of either climb all the way to the top. Somewhat reminiscent of the route Obsidian, although easier.

The excellent rock and highly technical moves make this a fun route to do after warming up on Lesbian Lust or one of the other nearby routes. Two, maybe three stars out of five.
content.location:
Located on the north side of the Zsa Zsa Gabor Memorial Boulder between the

Right Side Arete

and

Open Container

.

climbs.name: A Trip to the Tip
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Cyndie Bransford, George Armstrong

content.description:
East of and facing the Zsa Zsa Gabor Memorial Boulder is a large formation, the largest in the area, where this route is found.

Start on the southwest corner of the formation and climb a slab past three bolts (crux) into a thin, jagged crack (5.8) to finish on a ledge with some giant boulders. Gear belay and walk-off. One star out of five.
